newsitem.title: CROATIA: Croatia introduces its currency in Serb enclave.
newsitem.headline: Croatia introduces its currency in Serb enclave.

text.p: Croatia started on Monday introducing its currency in the Serb enclave of Eastern Slavonia, which is administered by the United Nations and due to revert to Croatian rule soon, U.N. officials and media said.

The introduction of the kuna is one of the most concrete signs of a transfer of rule in an area taken by the Serbs in 1991, when Croatia seceded from federal Yugoslavia, and the U.N. said it was going well.
Zagreb will fully retake the fertile enclave, bordering the Yugslav republic of Serbia to the east, after the current U.N. mandate expires on July 15.
"As of this morning kuna is the official means of payment in the area under U.N. control," Croatian state radio reported.
U.N. spokesman Yuriy Chizhik told Reuters the conversion of Yugoslav dinars into kuna, which will take another two days, "is going smoothly".
"Both kuna and dinar will be legal in the area for the next two months, with preferance to kuna," he said.
There are 25 post offices and seven bank branches where residents of Eastern Slavonia can convert dinars worth up to 2,000 kuna, said Chizhik.

Croatia's central bank has estimated the total amount of Yugoslav dinars in cash and deposits in the enclave amounts to 0.2 percent of the total money supply. It also said the conversion would not affect the stability of the kuna.
